notes:
1. Torsional Shear Stress

When a torque ($T$) is applied to a circular shaft, it induces shear stresses ($\tau$) on the cross-section. The stress varies linearly from zero at the center to a maximum at the outer surface.

$$ \tau = \frac{Tr}{J} $$
  • $T$: Internal torque.
  • $r$: Radial distance from the center.
  • $J$: Polar moment of inertia ($J = \pi c^4 / 2$ for solid shaft of radius $c$).

2. Angle of Twist

The angle of twist ($\phi$) measures the rotational deformation over the length ($L$) of the shaft.

$$ \phi = \frac{TL}{JG} $$

where $G$ is the shear modulus of the material.

3. Torsional Strain

The shear strain ($\gamma$) is related to the angle of twist:

$$ \gamma = \frac{r \phi}{L} $$

Maximum shear strain occurs at the surface: $\gamma_{max} = c \phi / L$.

solvedExamples.question: A solid steel shaft ($G = 80$ GPa) with a diameter of 50 mm is subjected to a torque of 1,000 NÂ·m. What is the maximum shear stress?
solvedExamples.explanation: Radius $c = 0.025$ m. Polar moment of inertia $J = \pi c^4 / 2 = \pi (0.025)^4 / 2 \approx 6.136 \times 10^{-7} \text{ m}^4$. Maximum stress $\tau_{max} = Tc/J = (1000)(0.025) / (6.136 \times 10^{-7}) \approx 40,743,000$ Pa = 40.7 MPa.

solvedExamples.question: If the length of a shaft is doubled while keeping torque and diameter constant, the angle of twist will:
solvedExamples.explanation: Based on the formula $\phi = TL/JG$, the angle of twist $\phi$ is directly proportional to the length $L$.
